summary: On January 28, 2019, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New Orleans entered a final judgment in favor of a defendant who was found guilty of aggravated rape in violation of the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in New Orleans, alleges that C.T., a Louisiana resident, was falsely told in closing arguments that he was going to be a "whole person" when, in fact, he was not a whole person. The complaint further alleges that defendant told his mother that he wanted to be "more like his mother and grandmother" and that he did not want to have a "whooping." The complaint also alleges that while he was in bed with his mother, D.A. told her that he had put his "private part" in her butt on more than one occasion, and that when she confronted him about it, he replied, "you want to know what he didn't do, he never shook his head no." The SEC alleges that the defendant was lying when he told her he had gotten a whooping.  According to the complaint, the defendant replied that he "didn't want to do it," and then told his mom that he would take his pants and underwear off and hit her with the belt on his back, his buttocks, and his hand. The SEC also alleged that defendant did not tell his mother what he had done to her.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Louisiana today announced criminal charges against D.T. for his role in the SEC's ongoing investigation of child sexual abuse, which has been conducted by staff in the agency's New Orleans Regional Office. The case is being supervised by Chedly C. Dumornay, Chief of the New Orleans Division of Criminal Investigations.
